text: Hi everyone. I'm proud to release v0.0.1 of Mech today, the first of many. It's more of a test-run to figure out how releases will work, so documentation will come with the next release v0.0.2. Still, I figured some people here might be interested to read a blog post and play with a little robot arm I wrote in Mech. Let me know any feedback you have! <http://mech-lang.org> and try it out online here <http://try.mech-lang.org|try.mech-lang.org>

elements.text: Hi everyone. I'm proud to release v0.0.1 of Mech today, the first of many. It's more of a test-run to figure out how releases will work, so documentation will come with the next release v0.0.2. Still, I figured some people here might be interested to read a blog post and play with a little robot arm I wrote in Mech. Let me know any feedback you have!
and try it out online here
try.mech-lang.org

text: i see your clock program. Not too far from Beads so can't be too critical hah. I do however think that the usage of [# space] to be a comment and [## space] to be a higher level comment is understandable, but having # prefix for an identifier to mean a tracked variable seems ill-advised. Why not use one of the other dozen punctuation characters like @ or % as a significant prefix. Seems way too dangerous to overload the comment delimiter with a functional prefix, when the only difference is a small space character. Makes it much harder to read; you are trying to train the eye to skip over the comments quickly and this will impede that training. So my criticism is about ergonomics. This is one of the things i hate about languages which overload the + operator. So plus can mean in some languages vector addition, string concatenation, all sorts of stuff. In FORTH you could redefine the + operator which was insane.

Why not use one of the other dozen punctuation characters like @ or % as a significant prefix. Seems way too dangerous to overload the comment delimiter with a functional prefix, when the only difference is a small space character. Makes it much harder to read; you are trying to train the eye to skip over the comments quickly and this will impede that training. So my criticism is about ergonomics. This is one of the things i hate about languages which overload the + operator. So plus can mean in some languages vector addition, string concatenation, all sorts of stuff. In FORTH you could redefine the + operator which was insane.

text: ## and # are just for markdown support. They're not really part of the language

elements.text: ## and # are just for markdown support. They're not really part of the language

text: When things are past this point and I have an actual editor, there won't be any # or ##

elements.text: When things are past this point and I have an actual editor, there won't be any # or ##

text: I like # for tables for the same reason we had them in Eve, because they have similar semantics to a # in Twitter, meaning a collection of things. I'm going to use a @ in the future to mean a specific row, which again will have semantics similar to Twitter

elements.text: I like # for tables for the same reason we had them in Eve, because they have similar semantics to a # in Twitter, meaning a collection of things. I'm going to use a @ in the future to mean a specific row, which again will have semantics similar to Twitter

text: i now have clock, wristwatch, tic-tac-toe, snake, chess, networked tic tac toe, and planning some for engineering use that employ lots of physical units, and then some for business that do your classic sum of territories sales report or stock portfolio.  Controlling a robot is a great idea. Sure wish Sony wasn't holding back on the Aibo; there isn't a commercial robot that is nimble that is open source yet to my knowledge. Huge mistake on Sony's part not to open it up to 3rd parties fully.

text: I am sure you have seen the boston dynamics stuff, but what we need is a consumer friendly priced robot chassis with enough quick motors and sensors to be be feasible, and then let people figure out how to make it do something useful.

elements.text: I am sure you have seen the boston dynamics stuff, but what we need is a consumer friendly priced robot chassis with enough quick motors and sensors to be be feasible, and then let people figure out how to make it do something useful.

text:
I'm planning on using Mech to control one of these: <https://www.sphero.com/sphero-bolt>

My goal is to get like 2 dozen and use them for a summer program for middle schoolers. We currently have a program at Lehigh where we use Matlab and iRobot creates. I think Mech and spheros would be a good upgrade

text: Thanks! I've been working toward getting this this robot arm drawing for almost a year. Next step is to make it do inverse kinematics, but I thought this was cool enough of a check point to do a release

text: Also, if you haven't looked at the code, this is using Josh's tagged math code, with some of my own fixes (I'm calling them "quantities" now). I'm not using any of the unit stuff yet, but that's coming.
